statement.text: Carotid duplex ultrasonography is the primary screening and surveillance modality for carotid stenosis. It uses B-mode imaging to visualize plaque and Doppler to measure blood flow velocities. Peak systolic velocity (PSV) and ICA/CCA ratio are used to grade stenosis: PSV >125 cm/s suggests ≥50% stenosis, PSV >230 cm/s suggests ≥70% stenosis.
statement.formal: Carotid Duplex: B-mode (plaque visualization) + Doppler (velocity measurement) | Velocity Criteria: PSV >125 cm/s → ≥50% stenosis | PSV >230 cm/s → ≥70% stenosis | ICA/CCA ratio >2 → ≥50%, >4 → ≥70%

explanation.intuition: When blood flows through a narrowed pipe, it speeds up like water through a pinched garden hose. Doppler ultrasound measures this velocity increase. The greater the stenosis, the faster the blood must travel to get through the narrowing. By measuring the peak systolic velocity in the internal carotid artery, we can estimate how tight the stenosis is without any needles, dye, or radiation.
explanation.key_insight: Duplex ultrasound is operator-dependent and velocity criteria vary slightly between labs. That's why most centers validate their velocity thresholds against angiography or CTA. When discrepancies arise or intervention is planned, confirmatory imaging (CTA or MRA) is often obtained.
explanation.technical_details: Standard examination: (1) B-mode imaging of CCA, bulb, ICA, ECA; (2) Color Doppler to identify stenosis location; (3) Spectral Doppler with angle correction (≤60°) at stenosis; (4) Measure PSV, end-diastolic velocity (EDV), and calculate ICA/CCA ratio. Additional features: plaque morphology (echogenicity, surface irregularity, ulceration), plaque thickness. Consensus velocity criteria (Society of Radiologists in Ultrasound): PSV <125 = <50%; PSV 125-230 = 50-69%; PSV >230 = ≥70%; No detectable flow = occlusion. Pitfalls: calcified plaque obscures B-mode; contralateral occlusion increases ipsilateral velocities; cardiac output affects velocities.
common_misconceptions: Duplex can diagnose exact stenosis percentage - it estimates stenosis ranges
All labs use the same criteria - velocity thresholds vary between laboratories
B-mode alone can grade stenosis - Doppler velocities are essential for grading
Duplex can see everything - intracranial disease, tandem lesions may be missed

definitions_glossary.duplex_ultrasound: Combined B-mode imaging and Doppler velocity measurement
definitions_glossary.end_diastolic_velocity: Blood velocity at end of diastole
definitions_glossary.ica_cca_ratio: Ratio of internal carotid to common carotid PSV
definitions_glossary.spectral_waveform: Graphical display of velocity over time

examination_protocol: Patient supine, head turned slightly away
Sample at maximum stenosis and standard locations

definition.@value: Noninvasive ultrasound modality combining B-mode imaging and Doppler to diagnose and grade carotid stenosis

sources.citation: Grant EG, et al. Carotid artery stenosis: gray-scale and Doppler US diagnosis--Society of Radiologists in Ultrasound Consensus Conference. Radiology. 2003;229(2):340-346.

learning_objectives: Describe the components of carotid duplex ultrasound
Apply velocity criteria to grade stenosis
clinical_pearls: Always consider confirmatory imaging before surgery
Echolucent plaque may be more 'dangerous' than calcified
Contralateral occlusion falsely elevates ipsilateral velocities
